Graphical abstract Bovine serum albumin (BSA)-templated CeO2 was prepared by citrate sol-gel method and used as a support to synthesize Au catalyst for benzene oxidation. It was found that the Au/BSA-CeO2 with 3.2 nm Au nanoparticles (NPs) gave rise to superior catalytic performance for benzene oxidation in which the temperature for 90 % benzene conversion was only 210 °C. In addition, the catalytic activity of Au/BSA-CeO2 remained stable for 140 h of on-stream reaction. Besides, density functional theory calculation demonstrated how the porous structure of CeO2 influenced the oxygen vacancy generation, and the synergetic effects of Au NPs and CeO2 support facilitated the activation of benzene which was adsorbed on Au NPs prior to benzene oxidation. The catalysis of benzene oxidation over Au/CeO2 catalyst follows the dual-site mechanism. BAS-templated CeO2 support possessed hierarchical structure, abundant adsorbed oxygen species and synergic interaction with Au that determined the performance of Au/BSA-CeO2. Keywords Bovine serum albumin template CeO2 Au nanoparticle catalyst Benzene oxidation Density functional theory calculation 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted from industrial manufacturing and transportation sectors are a major class of atmospheric pollutants, it is hence an urgent task to eliminate those noxious gases [1–3]. The destruction of VOCs by oxidation [2–4] operating at low temperature is considered to be effective and economic with high efficiency in which the key challenge is the availability of high-performance and environmentally friendly catalysts [5]. Benzene has been frequently used as a model VOC [6] to characterize the catalytic oxidation of VOCs owing to its high stability [7]. In recent years, supported noble metal catalysts have been widely used for benzene oxidation [8]. For instance, Pt/activated carbon has been used for complete oxidation of BTX (mixtures of benzene, toluene and Xylene) below 200 °C [9], and the activity of Pt catalyst was further improved with hydrophobic supports. Pt supported on Al2O3/Al monoliths was found to have high catalytic activities and be able to completely oxidize the studied VOCs (e.g., toluene, methyl ethyl ketone, acetone, and their mixtures) [10]. In addition, Au-based catalysts have gradually received extensive research interest in VOC oxidation ever since the successful applications of Au catalysts that were fabricated by dispersing Au nanoparticles (NPs) onto metal oxides, for catalyzing the oxidation of CO and mixture of hydrogen and CO at low temperature (<0 °C) with high efficiency [11,12]. Scirè et al. [13] compared catalytic activities of Au/Fe2O3, Ag/Fe2O3 and Cu/Fe2O3 for VOC oxidation and found that Au had the highest activity among the studied catalysts. The presence of Au rendered the bimetallic Pt-Au catalysts supported on ZnO/Al2O3 higher activity for toluene oxidation than monometallic Pt/ZnO/Al2O3, which was due to the weaker binding and flexibility [14] of the Au NPs that promoted catalytic reaction. In addition to the superior catalytic performance of Au catalysts, lower price of Au than Pt is another important factor making Au become attractive in the research and applications for VOC catalytic oxidation [15]. However, the performance of gold catalysts for VOC oxidation is highly dependent on the size of gold particles and the nature of the support [16]. Owing to the excellent oxygen storage capacity and redox properties [17], CeO2 has attracted attention for catalytic oxidation of VOCs [18,19]. For example, the utilization of CeO2 stabilized gold particles by enhancing the fixation and final dispersion of gold in the Au/Al2O3 catalysts and ceria improved the activity of gold particles in the oxidation of the tested VOCs. Fundamentally, the presence of a narrow Ce f-band and facile oxygen vacancy formation capacity [20,21] make CeO2 recognized as the best supporting materials for Au NPs-based catalysts [22]. The synergetic effect [23] between CeO2 and Au NPs enabled Au NPs to strongly bind to the vacancies enriched on CeO2 surface [24]. The structure of CeO2 has a great influence on its activity and stability [3,25]. Nano-size effect reveals that the decrease of CeO2 particle size facilitates the oxygen vacancy formation [26]. The mesoporous ceria has shown great potential as versatile catalysts and catalyst supports due to its high surface area given the defect-effect [27]. Large specific surface area and the hierarchical porous structures could provide more contents of surface oxygen vacancies that benefit the conversion of lattice oxygen to active oxygen [27]. For example, high benzene conversion was maintained at 220 °C in a test of 50-h duration for gold catalysts supported on the mesoporous CeO2 [28]. However, a major problem of CeO2 is its poor thermal stability, which is often caused by structure collapse during the step of surfactant removal at elevated temperatures in CeO2 synthesis [29]. Therefore, mesoporous CeO2 with an excellent thermal stability is highly desired for designing high performance catalysts. Although there are many methods for CeO2 preparation, such as thermal decomposition, sol-gel, precipitation, hydrothermal, and chemical template method, they have respective disadvantages [28–30]. For instance, the products of thermal decomposition and sol-gel methods are easy to sinter; precipitation method needs precise control of the generation rate of precipitants; hydrothermal method is expensive; and the process of chemical template method is complex while generating pollution [31,32]. Bio-template method has recently sparked research interest because of its structural diversity, low cost, convenience, and little environmental impact [33,34]. Acting as a space filler or a structure director, templates construct materials with hierarchical pore structure after the removal of themselves. For example, Mo-doped g-C3N4 fabricated with bio-template method exhibited an increased specific surface area and improved catalytic activity [35]. Biogenic Pd NPs were synthesized over the support of 3D porous KIT-6 to form Pd/kit-CeO2 catalysts which showed superior performance toward benzene oxidation [36]. For this method, choosing the right biological template for the system is critical to improving the thermal stability of CeO2 and the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Due to its conformations, compositions and spatial structures, protein becomes a potential and feasible bio-template for creating hierarchical pore in supports for catalyst synthesis. The multi-level and multi-dimensional BSA is a water-soluble globular protein that consists of 583 amino acid residues including 35 cysteine residues so that it can encapsulate and stabilize mental ions with its strong binding ability [37]. For example, BSA-incorporated Ag nanoflowers had an open nonporous structures with large surface area and been used as for biosensing [38–40]. The abundant secondary structures of BSA comprises of α-helix, β-sheet, β-turn, and random coil contributes to the formation of unique assembling structure under certain condition [41]. In this work, the BSA was used as a bio-template to prepare CeO2 with a hierarchically porous structures which served as supports to synthesize Au/CeO2 catalysts for benzene oxidation while the CeO2 support without using BSA template was studied in parallel as a control. The objectives of this research are to: (1) characterize the properties of CeO2 supports and Au/CeO2 catalysts to reveal the effects of BSA template on the synthesis of CeO2 supports and Au/CeO2 catalysts; (2) evaluate the catalytic performance and stability of Au/CeO2 catalysts on benzene oxidation; and (3) elucidate the effect of CeO2 porous structures on the generation of oxygen vacancy, and the effect of CeO2 porous structures and particle size on the benzene oxidation through the density functional theory (DFT) calculation. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3•6H2O, 99.95 %) and BSA (96 %) were purchased from Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Other chemical reagents in analytical grade were purchased from the Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Guangzhou, China) unless specified, otherwise. 2.2 Synthesis of CeO2 support The CeO2 support was prepared based on the BSA template. Specific procedures included: (i) 2.5 g Ce(NO3)3•6H2O and 3.63 g citric acid (the molar of Ce3+:citric acid = 1:3) were dissolved in 20 mL distilled water (DI), and the solution was stirred at 1,000 rpm at 65 °C for 24 h; ii 10 mL BSA solution of different BSA concentrations (i.e., 12.5, 25.0, 50.0, and 70.0 mg/mL) was added to the solution made in step (i), and stirred at 1,000 rpm for another 10 min until the mixture turned into milky white suspension; (iii) the suspension was aged at 70 °C for 24 h to form gel; and (iv) the gel was calcined to remove residual BSA in a muffle furnace at 350 or 600 °C for 3 h to obtain BSA-templated CeO2, denoted by BSA-CeO2. By following the same procedures, the CeO2 support without using BSA was also prepared and used for benzene oxidation as a control for comparison, denoted by none-CeO2. 2.3 Preparation of Au/CeO2 catalysts The Au/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by using NaOH deposition-precipitation method. Briefly, 520 μL HAuCl4 solution (1.0 g HAuCl4 dissolved in 50 mL DI water) was added into 10 mL DI water, and the pH was adjusted to about 9 by using 0.1 M NaOH followed by the addition of 0.25 g of BSA- or none-CeO2 made in Section 2.2. The solution stood at room temperature (RT) for 1 h before it was heated up to 65 °C and held at this temperature for another 1 h to generate precipitate. Such precipitate was then filtered, washed with DI water and dried at 50 °C for 5 h. Finally, the dry powder was calcined at 300 °C for 6 h to obtain Au NPs catalysts. The Au catalysts with BSA-CeO2 and none-CeO2 as supports were denoted by Au/BSA-CeO2 and Au/none-CeO2, respectively. In some specific experiments in this research, we used “typical” Au/BAS-CeO2 catalyst with 1.0 % of Au loading that was prepared with 70 mg/mL of BAS and calcined at 600 °C, unless otherwise noted. 2.4 Catalyst characterization The structures and properties of supports (BSA- and none-CeO2) and catalysts (Au/BSA- and Au/none-CeO2) were characterized by using different techniques. The BET surface areas were measured in a Micromeritics Tristar system (Tristar II3020, USA). Before the surface area measurement, all samples were degassed at 300 °C for 3 h. Power X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was done by using an X-ray diffractometer (RigakuUltima IV, Japan) with Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 30 mA). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging was conducted on a Tecnai F30 microscope (TECNAI F30, USA). The Raman spectra were characterized by employing inVia™ spectroscope (Renishaw, UK), in which the samples were exposed to laser output of 100 % with exposure time of 10 s (He-Ne light at 532 nm). The particle size of Au NPs of the catalysts was estimated by using the SigmaScan Pro software (SPSS Inc., Version 4.01.003). The actual Au loadings of the catalysts were determined by using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) (5100 SVDV, USA). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in the temperature range of 30–800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min with an air flow of 20 mL/min over a thermobalance (TG-209F1, Germany). Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted on a chemical adsorption analyzer (MFTP-3060, China) by using the H2-Ar (5/95, v/v) mixture as a reducing gas. Prior to the H2-TPR analysis, the samples were pretreated in Ar flow of 30 mL/min at 300 °C for 3 h to eliminate moisture and impurity, and the pretreated samples were heated from RT to 800 °C at a ramp heating rate of 5 °C/min in the aforementioned reducing gas at the flow rate of 50 mL/min to collect all peak signals. 2.5 Evaluation of catalyst performance on benzene oxidation The benzene oxidation was carried out in a continuous flow fixed-bed quartz microreactor (inner diameter = 5 mm). In the oxidation experiments, the amount of catalyst was 50 mg, and the total flow rate of the benzene/O2/N2 balance gases mixture was 16.7 mL/min with benzene concentration of 1,000 ppm, where the benzene/O2 molar ratio and space velocity (SV) were 1/400 and 20,000 mL/gcat/h, respectively. The balance of carbon throughout the experiments was estimated to be 99.6 %. To evaluate the stability of Au/BSA-CeO2 catalyst, the benzene oxidation experiment was continued for 140 h. As major oxidation products, water and CO2 were found to affect the catalytic benzene oxidation efficiency of Pd/kit-CeO2 so that we also tested the impact of water and CO2 on the catalysis of benzene oxidation by Au/CeO2 in this research. To study the effect of water vapor on catalytic performance, 5.0 vol% water vapor was introduced into the system by passing the reactant gases through a water saturator at 29 °C, while 10.0 vol% CO2 was added into the reaction system when studying the effect of CO2. Reactants and products were analyzed online with a gas chromatograph (GC-9160, Ouhua, China) which was equipped with double flame ionization detectors (FID). A SE-54 capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.5 μm) and a TDX-01 packed column (1 m × 2 mm) were used to analyze benzene and CO2 with N2 and Ar as carrier gases, respectively. The temperatures of gasification chamber, oven and detector were 240, 130 and 250 °C, respectively. 2.6 DFT calculation The Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) was used to perform all the DFT calculations [30,33]. Core electron effect on the valence electron density was described by using the Projector Augmented Wave (PAW) [42]. The exchange-correlation effect was determined with the generalized gradient approximation of the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) version [43]. The cutoff energy for the plane wave basis sets was approximate 400 eV. The conjugated gradient method was used to optimize the atoms and the cell parameters. In addition, the convergence thresholds have been set to 10−5 eV and 10−2 eV/Å for the input energy and the force, respectively. The interactions of the periodic images were avoided by employing a vacuum space larger than 20 Å along the Z direction. The Brillouin zone was sampled by Monkhorst-Pack-points mesh of 1 × 1×1 for structure optimization and 3 × 3×3 for static self-consistent field calculation of electronic structures. On-site coulomb interactions of Ce 4f electrons were employed to demonstrate the DFT + U with the value of Ueff (Ce) = 4.5 eV. The adsorption energy was typically obtained based on the following formula: Ea (benzene) = E (benzene-Au/CeO2) − E (Au/CeO2) − E (benzene), where E (benzene-Au/CeO2), E (Au/CeO2) and E (benzene) were single-point free energy of relaxed geometry of benzene-Au/CeO2, Au/CeO2 and benzene, respectively with the same computational settings. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of CeO2 support and Au/CeO2 catalyst 3.1.1 Characterization of CeO2 support The XRD patterns of BSA- and none-CeO2 are shown in Fig. 1 . The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 28.5, 33.0, 47.4, and 56.3° are assigned to (111), (200), (220), and (311) crystal planes, respectively. They belong to the characteristic peaks of the cubic fluorite structured CeO2 (JCPDS No. 34-0394). There is no crystal phase peak of other substances in the Fig. 1, indicating that the product CeO2 support had high purity and the presence of BSA didn’t cause change in crystal phase. In addition, the half peak width of BSA-CeO2 is larger than that of none-CeO2, and the grain size of BSA-CeO2 is smaller than that of none-CeO2 according to the Debye-Scherrer formula. The SEM images of BSA- and none-CeO2 are shown in Fig. 2 . It can be seen that BSA-CeO2 is a porous metal oxide with different pore diameters, while the none-CeO2 has much fewer pores. In the presence of BSA during BSA-CeO2 fabrication, BSA chelated with Ce3+ (the precursor of CeO2) and formed pores after the removal of BSA molecules by calcination, compared to none-CeO2. In order to further explore the pore structure of BSA-CeO2, its pore size distribution was analyzed with BET. As shown in Fig. S1, BSA-CeO2 exhibits the hierarchical pores, and the pore size mainly centers around 8.4, 22.0 and 35.3 nm, while the pore size of none-CeO2 centers around 3.1 nm. TEM images (Fig. 3 ) show the none-CeO2 exhibits the planar structure of the polygon inlaid, while the BSA-CeO2 is in the form of dispersed and spherical grains. Furthermore, the size of BSA-CeO2 grains is smaller than that of none-CeO2, which is consistent with the XRD analysis results (Fig. 1). The possible reason for such results is that the BSA molecules confined the CeO2 precursor and prevented the CeO2 particles from sintering during the fabrication of CeO2, making the size of BSA-CeO2 smaller. In addition to the morphology studies, the BET surface area, pore diameter and pore volume of none- and BSA-CeO2 were also quantified and are shown in Table 1 . It can be seen that the use of the BSA template led to the increase of both specific surface area and pore volume of CeO2. Furthermore, both specific surface area and pore volume were found to positively correlate with the amount of BSA template used in CeO2 preparation. The oxygen vacancy of CeO2 can promote the oxygen adsorption and activation while active oxygen species can be generated through the interaction of CeO2 and oxygen molecules, which is beneficial to oxidation. Therefore, the oxygen vacancy is one of the important properties of CeO2 and was studied by using Raman spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 4 , a characteristic peak of fluorite structure F2g at 458 cm−1 and a weak peak RD at 598 cm-1 were found for all CeO2 prepared with different amount of BSA, which are resulted from lattice defect, including oxygen vacancy. In order to maintain the electron neutrality of the CeO2 grain, lattice oxygen escapes from the crystal structure, resulting in the formation of oxygen vacancy. As shown in Table 1, the area ratios of F2g peak to RD peak [A(F2g)/A(RD)] for all the BSA-CeO2 are higher than that for none-CeO2. In addition, more BSA led to higher A(F2g)/A(RD) in the range of BSA from 0 to 0.7 g used for CeO2 preparation. In sum, the utilization of BSA template in CeO2 preparation benefited the increase of the specific surface area and oxygen vacancy concentration, which was expected to promote the catalytic oxidation with the Au catalysts over such BSA-CeO2 supports. 3.1.2 Characterization of Au/CeO2 catalyst The XRD patterns of Au/none- and Au/BSA-CeO2 are presented in Fig. 5 . XRD pattern of Au/BSA-CeO2 shows the diffraction peak of Au (111) crystal plane, while there is no detectable diffraction peak of Au for Au/none-CeO2, indicating little Au content in Au/none-CeO2. Quantification of Au loading confirmed (Table 2 ) that the actual Au loading of Au/BSA-CeO2 is about 3–4 folds higher than that of Au/none-CeO2. The small pore size and pore volume of none-CeO2 (Table 1) may make it difficult for Au particles to deposit on the inner surfaces of CeO2. On the contrary, BSA-CeO2 exhibited larger pore size and volume as well as specific surface area that offer more deposition sites from Au particles, prompting the deposition of Au particles on the inner surface and improving the load capacity of Au. Meanwhile, the TEM images (Fig. 6 ) show that Au particles of Au/none-CeO2 are slightly larger than that of Au/BSA-CeO2 (3.9 vs. 3.2 nm). 3.2 Catalytic performance of Au/CeO2 towards benzene oxidation 3.2.1 Influence of BSA dosage Fig. 7 shows the catalytic performance of Au/BSA- and Au/none-CeO2 on benzene oxidation. It can be seen that all Au/BSA-CeO2 catalysts had better catalytic performance on benzene oxidation than Au/none-CeO2, and the increase of BSA amount (from 0 to 0.7 g) enhanced the catalyst performance. For example, the temperature required for 90 % benzene conversion (T90 %) was 210 °C for Au/BSA-CeO2 prepared with 0.7 g BSA, while it increased to 270 °C for Au/none-CeO2 catalyst. Overall, the catalysts prepared with higher BSA loading need lower temperature to achieve the same benzene conversion. These results indicate that the structure of the BSA-templated CeO2 support is beneficial to enhance the catalytic performance of the supported Au catalyst on benzene oxidation owing to its hierarchically porous structure with large surface area and oxygen vacancies. Compared to other reported catalyst, such as Au/ MnO2 (T90 %=250 °C) [44], Au/c-Co3O4 (T90 %=272 °C) [45], Ag2/eggshell (T90 %=257 °C) [46], and Ag/α-MnO2 (T90 %=295 °C) [47], the Au/BSA-CeO2 in this paper exhibits better catalytic performance. 3.2.2 Influence of calcination temperature The calcination temperature for BSA-CeO2 preparation was found to significantly impact the catalytic performance of Au/BSA-CeO2 on benzene oxidation (Fig. 8 ). The calcination temperature of 600 °C resulted in higher catalytic activity of Au/BSA-CeO2 than 350 °C. It was found that the actual Au loading of Au/BSA-CeO2 and specific area of BSA-CeO2 support calcined at 600 °C are higher and smaller than the counterparts calcined at 350 °C (Tables 2 and S1), respectively. According to the TEM images (Fig. S2), the grain size of the BSA-CeO2 calcined at 350 °C was about 10 nm which is smaller than that of the BSA-CeO2 calcined at 600 °C (about 20 nm) while the former grains are more packed. The XRD patterns and TEM images of Au/BSA-CeO2 with the BSA-CeO2 supports being calcined at different temperatures are presented in Figs. S3 and S4. Both XRD patterns show similar Au (111) diffraction peaks. It is difficult to distinguish Au NPs from CeO2 grains in the TEM image due to the ultrafine CeO2 grains calcined at 350 °C. As such, we were not able to measure the diameter of Au particle even though there is 1.63 % Au loading (Table 2) on the BSA-CeO2 calcined at 350 °C. To sum up, the amount of available active sites on Au appears to be more important than the specific surface area to determine the catalyst activity while the active sites on Au are the main location where benzene molecules react with oxygen species. 3.3 Stability of Au/BSA-CeO2 catalyst The typical Au/BSA-CeO2 catalyst was used for the tests in this section. As shown in Fig. 9 , the benzene conversion stayed above 90 % over 140 h, which indicated the excellent stability of the catalyst. By comparing the TEM images (Fig. S5) for the catalyst before and after reaction, it can be seen that the Au NPs and the crystal grains of CeO2 support have little change in size. In addition, the Au NPs on the support is still well dispersed after 140 h of benzene oxidation. As the TG curves shows in Fig. S6, the raw and used catalysts had little weight losses (1.8 and 1.6 %, respectively), indicating that the Au/BSA-CeO2 surface is unlikely to be blocked by the reaction products (causing catalyst deactivation) during the catalytic benzene oxidation process. The structure of the active catalytic sites of Au/BSA-CeO2 seem to have little change, which is critical in maintaining the catalysis activity of Au/BSA-CeO2. To examine the effect of water vapor (one of products of benzene oxidation) on the catalytic activity of Au/BSA-CeO2, benzene oxidation experiments in the presence of 5.0 vol% water vapor was carried out for 250 h and showed that the benzene conversion reduced from 92 to 85 % (Fig. 10 ), which could be due to the competitive adsorption between water vapor and benzene on Au/BSA-CeO2. When the water vapor supply was cut off, the benzene conversion rate restored to the original level. Such results indicated that water vapor didn’t result in irreversible deactivation of Au/BSA-CeO2, i.e., water vapor didn’t alter the structural integrity of the Au/BSA-CeO2 during benzene oxidation. In addition to water, CO2 is the other main product of benzene oxidation, and may affect the catalytic activity of Au/BSA-CeO2 during benzene conversion. As shown in Fig. 11 , the presence of 10 vol% CO2 reduced the benzene conversion from 92 to 86 %, while the benzene conversion completely resumed to the normal level when CO2 was removed. Such results indicated that CO2 could cause reversible poisoning of Au/BSA-CeO2 through the deposition of carbonate species on the surface of Au/BSA-CeO2. 3.4 Mechanism of BSA in the synthesis of Au/BSA-CeO2 catalyst BSA was used as a bio-template to prepare BSA-CeO2 support in this research. When BSA solution was added to the hydrosol system (i.e., Ce-sol) formed by the reaction of cerium nitrate and citric acid, the Ce-sol accumulated in the BSA molecular space resulting in a rapid increase of molecular weight. The transparent hydrosol was instantaneously converted to a milky white suspension. Meanwhile, the multi-level and multi-dimensional structure of BSA played a role in dispersing and confining the metal complexes in the hydrosol, i.e., the CeO2 precursor sols were compartmentalized to form Ce-Gel (Fig. 12 ). The fresh Ce-Gel sample was then aged and dried to obtain a cake-shaped dry Ce-Gel. Finally, the dry Ce-Gel was calcined to remove BSA molecules, a large amount of gaseous species, such as H2O, CO2, SO2, and NO2 are generated during the pyrolysis process. These generated gases evaporate and leave more pores, resulting in porous structure of BSA-CeO2 with dispersed and spherical CeO2 crystal grains. In contrast, CeO2 fabricated without the use of BSA template had few empty channels, and CeO2 crystal grains were tightly packed in a polygon inlay pattern. Therefore, the presence of BSA can prevent the CeO2 precursor from agglomerating during drying while retarding the agglomeration of CeO2 crystal grains. As such, the grains of BSA-templated CeO2 have better dispersion, as shown in Fig. 3. 3.5 DFT calculations Benzene adsorption, one of key steps in catalytic oxidation is always used to identify the effect of porous CeO2 on the catalytic property. This research used the VASP software to carry out the DFT calculation. Owing to the restriction of computational cost and methods, it is difficult to completely reproduce experimental model of the supporting Au particle with the size of 3.2 nm. To build appropriate computational model, we used the Au55 particle (diameter = 11.293 Å) loaded on the stable (111) plane of three types of model CeO2 supports which are non-pore, small-pore (diameter = 7.778 Å) and large-pore (diameter = 12.386 Å). The optimized models of an oxygen vacancy on pristine CeO2, outside surface oxygen vacancy (OSOV) and inside surface oxygen vacancy (ISOV) on defective porous CeO2 are show in Fig. S7. The formation energy of an oxygen vacancy, Ev, is estimated by the formula Ev = ECeO2-x + 1/2 EO2–ECeO2, where ECeO2-x represents the energy of a reduced CeO2 surface containing an oxygen vacancy. ECeO2 and EO2 are the energy of optimal stoichiometric CeO2 surface and an O2 molecule, respectively. The Ev for pristine CeO2, OSOV- CeO2 and ISOV- CeO2 are 2.4482, -1.2799 and -1.2786 eV, respectively. The result reveals that porous structures of CeO2 can induce the generation of oxygen vacancy more easily with a lower required energy. Then the oxygen vacancies benefit the conversion of lattice oxygen to active oxygen. This part gives an excellent explanation towards our topic of porous CeO2 structure have more oxygen vacancy and better catalytic performance. We studied the adsorption sites (CeO2 support, Au55 particle and interface site between CeO2 and Au55) of benzene on three kinds of Au/CeO2 catalysts. The calculation results of adsorption energy in the case of non-pore indicate that benzene is more stable when it is adsorbed at the interface between CeO2 and Au55. However, when the small- or large-pore of the CeO2 support exists, benzene prefers to adsorb on Au NPs (Fig. 13 ). The adsorption energies for non-pore, small-pore and large-pore are -0.2204, -2.2781 and -0.9315 eV, respectively. The calculation results for adsorption site and adsorption energy show that the presence of pores on Au55/CeO2 and the size of pores have significant effects on benzene adsorption. In observing the optimized model of Au55 deposition on CeO2, we realize that Au is located above CeO2 instead of embedding in it, in the case of none-pore and small-pore. However, Au55 is partially embedded in the support and deformed in the case of large-pore, resulting in the change of the active site of Au55. Meanwhile, the optimized model of benzene adsorption shows that the bond length of benzene has changed and become longer (the bond length changed as follows: 0.00383 Å for non-pore, 0.00216 Å for small-pore and 0.0043 Å for large-pore), which means benzene is activated after adsorption. The charge calculation results show that non-pore, small-pore and large-pore size of Au/CeO2 catalysts have 0.1568, 0.1028 and 0.1647 electron from benzene molecules and Au lost 0.3244, 0.5047 and 0.3997 to CeO2, respectively. The charge difference further explains the effect of pore size on the adsorption of benzene molecules, and the transfer of electrons from Au to the support renders the metal exhibit better catalytic performance. It is feasible to conclude that the more electrons transferred from Au to CeO2 the better can benzene adsorb on the catalyst with lower adsorption energy. Furthermore, Electron Location Functional (ELF) computation results (Fig. 14 ) also indicate that the electron clouds around benzene are more uniform in the case of small- or large-pores. Meanwhile, benzene is activated with the increase of the pore size. Thus, benzene activation can be attributed to the synergetic effect of Au NPs and porous CeO2. At last, we performed projected density of states (PDOS) calculation, as shown in Fig. 15 . The overlap of 2p states of C in benzene and O, 4d states of Au and 4f states of Ce is -1.55 eV below Fermi level. This phenomenon further demonstrates the synergistic effect of porous CeO2 and Au clusters on the benzene ring adsorption. 3.6 Mechanism of benzene oxidation over Au/CeO2 The H2-TPR curves of Au/BSA- and Au/none-CeO2 are shown in Fig. 16 . The introduction of Au to the catalyst facilitated the reduction of oxygen species on the CeO2 surface. The reduction temperatures of the boundary between Au particles and BSA-CeO2 supports (calcined at 600 and 350 °C) were 89 and 105 °C, respectively, which were lower than that of Au/none-CeO2 (114 °C). The lower reduction temperature indicated stronger interactions between Au NPs and the support in Au/BSA-CeO2, which led to higher activity of surface oxygen species and weakened the Ce-O bond. Thereby the reactivity of the oxygen species on the CeO2 surface was enhanced. Of surface oxygen species on CeO2, the superoxide species O2 − is considered as the oxygen source for benzene oxidation over Au/CeO2 catalyst. Thus, the benzene oxidation over Au/CeO2 obeys the dual-sites mechanism similar to the CO oxidation over Au/CeO2 and Pd/CeO2, which is expressed as Eqs. (1) – (4) and shown in Fig. 17 . The benzene molecules are mainly adsorbed on Au particles to form the interface between Au and the benzene, which will move to the boundary of Au particle and CeO2 through surface diffusion. Oxygen molecules are activated by electrons in the oxygen vacancy to form O2 − while Ce3+ is oxidized to Ce4+. Au-C6H6 reacts with O2 − at the interface to produce CO2, and the electrons are left to reduce Ce4+ to Ce3+. One redox cycle is finished once the catalyst surface recovers. Therefore, the reduction of Au particle size can increase the benzene diffusion rate and the boundary length, which is beneficial to benzene oxidation. (1) O2 + Ce3+-□→ O2 − + Ce4+-□ (2) C6H6 + Au → Au-C6H6 (3) Au-C6H6 + 3O2 − → CO2 + Au + e (4) Ce4+-□ + e → Ce3+-□ Where, the □ represents the oxygen vacancy. 4 Conclusions Bio-templated CeO2 with BSA was fabricated and used as a support to synthesize Au/BSA-CeO2 catalysts for catalytic benzene oxidation. The CeO2 prepared without BSA (none-CeO2) served as a control. The presence of BSA template rendered CeO2 a hierarchically porous structure. Compared to the control, the BSA template increased the pore size, pore volume and specific surface area of CeO2 while retarding the sintering and size growth of CeO2 grains. Therefore, the grains of BSA-templated CeO2 had better dispersion. The BSA molecules play dual roles in dispersing and capping the CeO2 precursor sol. The hierarchically porous BSA-CeO2 support enriched with oxygen vacancies and was beneficial to prepare Au NPs-based catalyst with smaller size and higher actual Au loading. Also, the Au NPs were better dispersed onto the surface of BSA-CeO2 compared to none-CeO2. The Au/BSA-CeO2 exhibited better catalytic performance on the benzene oxidation than Au/none-CeO2 (e.g., the former had T90 % = 210 °C, and its activity remained stable over 140 h of on-stream reaction). DFT calculation demonstrated that the porous structure of CeO2 promoted the generation of oxygen vacancies and the synergetic effect of CeO2 support and Au NPs. In benzene oxidation, the benzene molecules are mainly adsorbed on Au particles while reactive oxygen species are generated by oxygen vacancy of CeO2. Then the adsorbed benzene molecules react with the active oxygen species. This work successfully demonstrated the potential advantages of bio-templated catalysts for VOC oxidation, which could provide a different research direction in the development of bio-based support for catalyst synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Bovine serum albumin (BSA)-templated CeO2 was prepared by citrate sol-gel method and used as a support to synthesize Au catalyst for benzene oxidation. It was found that the Au/BSA-CeO2 with 3.2 nm Au nanoparticles (NPs) gave rise to superior catalytic performance for benzene oxidation in which the temperature for 90 % benzene conversion was only 210 °C. In addition, the catalytic activity of Au/BSA-CeO2 remained stable for 140 h of on-stream reaction. Besides, density functional theory calculation demonstrated how the porous structure of CeO2 influenced the oxygen vacancy generation, and the synergetic effects of Au NPs and CeO2 support facilitated the activation of benzene which was adsorbed on Au NPs prior to benzene oxidation. The catalysis of benzene oxidation over Au/CeO2 catalyst follows the dual-site mechanism. BAS-templated CeO2 support possessed hierarchical structure, abundant adsorbed oxygen species and synergic interaction with Au that determined the performance of Au/BSA-CeO2.
coredata.dc:title: Bovine serum albumin templated porous CeO2 to support Au catalyst for benzene oxidation
